Title: How Codebases Become Spaghetti – Dev Leader Weekly 67
Description: Welcome to another issue of Dev Leader Weekly! In this issue, I discuss how codebases grow in complexity with an example -- AND what to do!

Title: Classic 3D videogame shadow techniques
Description: Towards the end of Wim Wenders’s excellent Perfect Days, the protagonist Hirayama is drinking beer under a bridge after he has seen a Businessman courting his crush. Suddenly the Businessman joins him under the bridge. As it turns out, things aren’t actually that simple but the point is their conversation takes them to some fundamental questions:

Title: The Role of Mentoring for New Devs
Description: If you want to learn #programming make sure to get a mentor when you hit THIS roadblock! An extract from my recent talk with Nick Consentino #mentoring #programminghelp

Title: Synchronous buck converter for 12V/5A output
Description:
What is the logical next step after making a linear
regulator? I learned some valuable lessons
(both regarding general electronics and power supplies) doing that
project, so I believe I could now make a much better linear
supply. And perhaps I will! But now I decided it was time to aim for a
switch-mode power supply (SMPS), a.k.a DC/DC converter.

Title: The Intelligence of Noetic Fields
Description: Alan Briskin and I are working on a book about “fields.” I have written several previous posts about them. The map to this territory is becoming clearer and more detailed as we, along with David Sibbet, Gisela Wendling, Karen Buckley, and Philip Bakerlaar share our ideas and experiences  about and with fields. We are also investigating the work of those who have explored social fields before us like Mary Parker Follett, Kurt Lewin, Pierre Bourdieu, David Bohm, Lynne McTaggart, and Otto Scharmer. The following piece is an adaptation of writings and conversations between Alan and myself.

Title: Building Moment chapter 1: I had no idea what I was doing
Description:
I built my business blind. Not "Ray Charles" blind, but "pilot flying in fog" blind. Except I didn't have any instruments.


I incorporated right out of university. The business was Debuggex Inc., and the first product was a regex debugger. This was an ultra-niche (I didn't realize just how niche
